Purdue University has defined a challenging vision to achieve preeminence, and the Purdue Polytechnic Institute has mapped out the steps necessary to make that vision a reality so that we can compete and thrive in this century and beyond.
The college will focus on three key signature areas:
Each investment you make strengthens our college and fosters ingenuity and creativity from our students and faculty. The following pages are designed to help you find your passion.
We thank you for your support!

New scholarship fund at Purdue Polytechnic Columbus honors Minnicks

A new endowed scholarship at Purdue Polytechnic Columbus honors the late Helen and Adrian Minnick, who were active in promoting both educational and community initiatives.         The first Helen and Adrian Minnick Scholarship will be awarded in fall 2018 to a student pursuing a degree at Purdue Polytechnic Columbus.         The scholarship was created through a gift from the Minnicks’ daughter, Sandra Oliverio (’64 HHS – Foods & Nutrition in Business). Oli...
Niswonger atrium receives new bench dedicated to departed alumnus

The faculty and staff of Purdue’s School of Aviation Technology unveiled the newly dedicated William "Will" T. Goshorn bench in the Niswonger Aviation Technology Building at the Purdue University Airport on April 22.         Goshorn, an AT ’98 graduate, had two great loves: Purdue University and flying. After his passing, his family and friends received donations from Goshorn’s memorial service to commission the custom bench.         The dedication welcome...
Sadowski Fund will support Polytechnic diversity efforts

Mary Sadowski received her doctorate in Education from Purdue in 1984. She joined the faculty and earned tenure in the Department of Computer Graphics Technology before departing for a position at Arizona State University. Sadowski returned to Purdue in 2003 as associate dean for undergraduate programs in the Purdue Polytechnic Institute (formerly the College of Technology). Over the course of many years at Purdue, Sadowski also was dean of the Purdue Extended Campus and special advisor to th...
New plane, scholarships, meeting to impact persons with disabilities

June 12, 2015, may be remembered as a banner day for persons with disabilities interested in flight and aviation careers.         That is the day when:             Purdue celebrated the gift of a Sky Arrow L600 for participants in the Able Flight program          the Coalition to Salute America’s Heroes helped pay for two pilots to complete the program          a foundation announced it would help fund scholarships, and          industry leaders held a brainstorming session to...
R.E. Dimond 40th Anniversary gift improves opportunities for Engineering Technology students

Financial support by R.E. Dimond and Associates, an Indianapolis-based engineering consulting firm, is benefiting learning-in-context curricula in Purdue Polytechnic’s Applied Energy Lab, which is directed by Bill Hutzel, professor of mechanical engineering technology.         A portion of the gift provided funding for electrical work managed by Wil Arnett, a graduate research assistant in the School of Engineering Technology, on the recent replacement of Knoy Hall’s roof...
Sheehans have supported an “educated future” for 26 years

Two scholarships established by Thomas J. (HDR ’08 TECH; MS ’65 ECE; BS ’64 ECE) and M. Judith Sheehan are benefitting Purdue Polytechnic students.         The Sheehan Family Scholarship supports student athletes majoring in engineering, science, or technology at the West Lafayette campus.         The Thomas and Rosemary Sheehan Scholarship provides merit-based support for students pursuing a degree at Purdue Polytechnic Kokomo. Preference for this scholarship, provided to h...
Remick Endowment demonstrates unwavering Purdue commitment

Once Jim Remick joined the Purdue Technology Dean’s Council in 1990, his support of the Purdue Polytechnic Institute became continuous, even though he passed away in December of 2016. Remick designated the Purdue Foundation as a beneficiary in his life insurance policy, and his unique gift supports the Jim and Sheli Remick Endowment.         Remick and his wife, Sheli, initially funded the endowment in 2004 to support students and faculty in the college, known then as the Schoo...
Notary Memorial Scholarship continues to help construction management students

The family and friends of a construction management technology student who died weeks before his 2013 graduation have created a scholarship in his memory.         Donations for the Scott A. Notary Memorial Scholarship, first solicited in fall 2014, successfully funded a $25,000 endowment by early 2015. Students in the School of Construction Management Technology have been awarded Notary Memorial scholarships since the 2015-16 academic year.         “Scott’s good nature en...
Bertoline Family Scholarship benefits in-state students

Gary Bertoline, dean and distinguished professor in the Purdue Polytechnic Institute, and his wife Ada recognized a need for financial aid for students in the college. The Bertolines took advantage of the Indiana Challenge Match, which doubled their donation, and established the Bertoline Family Scholarship in 2012. The fund benefits in-state students pursuing a degree in Purdue Polytechnic.         The endowment began funding scholarships for the 2014-15 school year. Since then, the...

Combine your personal and career life while earning a Purdue degree

The Purdue Polytechnic Institute at Lafayette is part of a statewide network that offers the same technology degrees available in West Lafayette. The benefit of earning your degree at the Lafayette location is that the campus is small enough to provide you with dedicated, one-to-one attention while you earn your degree from Purdue University.

Purdue Polytechnic Lafayette, located on the Subaru manufacturing campus in Lafayette, is designed for working adults with classes offered during the day and evening so that you can continue to meet your work and family obligations. Our unique approach allows you to combine both your personal and career life while earning a college degree.

Submissions for this form are closed.

Prospective students and their family members have options for visiting Purdue Polytechnic Institute on the Purdue University campus. The visit(s) you choose depend on your personal interests, sight-seeing goals and where you are in your college selection process.
Note: Airport visit is not included and must be scheduled separately.
The walking tour of Purdue Polytechnic Institute takes place inside Knoy Hall. The tour visits the following Polytechnic academic departments/schools:
Department of Computer and Information Technology
Specialized tours of the Polytechnic’s School of Aviation and Transportation Technology department are taken separately from Polytechnic Information Sessions.
Purdue University offers options for prospective students who wish to visit campus, ranging from a few hours to all day.
Office of Recruitment, Retention and Diversity
within the Purdue Polytechnic offers camps for middle and high school students throughout the year.
